4.text: Look around you and name something that you can see. For example, a tree or a cup

21.text: Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”

32.text: Countdown from 5 and make the shape of a tree with your bodies. Be as big and silly as possible.

52.text: Now let your child have a turn. What can they see?

63.text: If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside.

79.text: When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!

92.text: Start the story with “Once upon a time there was a…”

103.text: Let your child make up the next sentence

111.text: Then you make up a sentence

117.text: Take turns until you have a wonderful new story

126.text: Make sure to end the story on a positive note.

136.text: Ask your child what was their favourite part of the story!

148.text: Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds.

163.text: Ask your child “If you had the superpower to […] how would you use it?

178.text: Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out.

191.text: Now let them choose a super power for you

200.text: Make sure you act it out too!

210.text: Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat or flying a plane

227.text: Say them to your child and ask, “Which would you prefer?”

241.text: Now think of three more situations or ask your child to do it for you

260.text: Lie on your tummies and pretend your index fingers are a wiggly worm.

274.text: With your other hand make a worm house by making a circle with your fingers and thumb and place it on the floor.

298.text: Call out an instruction for your finger to touch, like “Worms on noses” or “Worms on ears”

315.text: When you call out “Worms go home”, your wiggly worm has to find a worm house as quickly as possible.

336.text: The last worm to find a home calls out the instructions next.

349.text: Keep playing until you feel rejuvenated from lying down.

1188.text: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:

1203.text: 1. Take a deep breath before you respond.

1212.text: 2. Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.

1225.text: 3. Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"

1240.text: 4. Reassure your child that you are there for them.

1251.text: 5. You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.

1266.text: 6. Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.

1277.text: 7. Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.

1815.text: Create a dance choreography to your children’s favorite songs

1824.text: First person does a dance move and everyone else copies.

1835.text: Everyone takes turns being the leader

1847.text: This game can be played in pairs or even as a group

1859.text: Stand facing each other or in a circle

1869.text: One person leads first while everyone else must copy, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.

1889.text: Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.

1909.text: After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead

1929.text: Play music or someone sings a song, and everyone dances

1939.text: When the music stops, everyone must freeze

1946.text: Last person still dancing becomes the judge for the next round

2384.text: Tell the story about a ferocious dragon who lived near a village. He would sneak into the village at night and steal people’s treasures – anything they loved.  Anybody who tried to take their treasure back would be eaten alive.  This continued for many years until the dragon became old, fat, and blind from sitting on his treasure and gazing at the glare of the gold coins. Then the townspeople could try and sneak into his lair and steal back their relatives’ treasure.

2993.text: We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.

3039.text: Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves!

3069.text: Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:

3078.text: Step 1. Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

3115.text: Step 2. Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'

3143.text: Step 3. Praise with enthusiasm. Really mean it when you say it!

3155.text: Praise your children when they are behaving well! They may not show it but you’ll see them doing that good behaviour again…

3177.text: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Try to find 3 things that you can praise your children for every day. You can also praise other adults in your household, too. Notice how they respond!

3215.text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat to you later!

3235.text: Invest in One-on-One Time! The more time you spend with your children, the more likely they will listen to you and behave well at other times. It really works!

7709.text: It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Many of us were told not to cry when we were sad or laugh when we were happy. This may be especially the case for boys and men.

7755.text: Talking about feelings can help children manage anger, disappointment, and frustration. It can also help your child be more aware of positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness. It can also allow children to appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!

7801.text: 6. Show your child that you care

7808.text: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved. A hug or saying, "I understand," can mean a lot. Remind your child that you are there for them and that they can always talk to you.

7849.text: But we all have the same feelings, and  we can learn how to become aware of our own emotions, to experience them in our body, and to communicate about them.

7880.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about talking about emotions?

11953.text: We are sorry to hear that you have been having some difficulties spending One-on-One Time with your children. Please type "Help" for other advice that might be of use to you. Thank you for trying your best!

11990.text: It can be hard to find time during your day, with work, chores, and everything else. Can you think of a time each day that you can make 5 minutes or a bit more? You can even make household chores into a game to do together. Even 5 minutes can make a big difference!

12045.text: It can make you feel bad if your children do not want to spend One-on-One Time you. Think to yourself: When are they more open to you? Maybe in the morning or right before bedtime.

12080.text: Children often to want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Sometimes you might want to give them some other fun options to do instead (Type: "Help" if you want a suggestion).

12115.text: If your child wants to do things that are too difficult for you to physically do, you can simply watch your child. Try describing what they are doing like a sports announcer and praising what they do!

12152.text: Competitive games can be challenging for children (and adults!) if they have difficulty losing. You may want to suggest other activities that you can play together instead of against each other (Type "Help" if you want a suggestion").

12190.text: If your child is very young, it is normal for them to have a short attention span and want to do many things during One-on-One Time. Just accept your child and follow their lead moving from one activity to the next.

12231.text: You can also find something educational to do together with your child on the gadget. Or maybe ask your child to show you what is their favourite thing to do on the gadget. Just be patient. Soon they may open up to other activities, too!

12276.text: Sometimes our children will suggest activities that are violent or unsafe. Explain why they can't, and try suggesting alternative activities that would be more appropriate. Type "Help" if you want a suggestion.

12308.text: You can also just sit next to your child while they are doing something they enjoy (like watching a T.V. show) and show them that you are interested in what they like. If you take their lead they will see that you care.

12351.text: The end of One-on-One Time can sometimes be difficult for your child. Try giving your child a Transition Warning about a minute before the end of One-on-One Time: "In one minute, One-on-One Time will be over and it will be time to wash our hands before dinner..."

12398.text: It can be difficult to spend One-on-One Time with each one child when you have more than one child. If possible, you can ask another adult or older sibling to look after the other children while you spend One-on-One Time with one child.

12442.text: If your child is too young to understand how long a minute is, then you can set a number of time to repeat the activity: "5 more tries and then it will be time for wash our hands before dinner…"

12482.text: You can also think of times when it would be easier to spend One-on-One Time each child, like later in the evening with an older child after the others have gone to sleep.

12515.text: Only give the transition warning once. When One-on-One Time is over, thank your child for spending time with you. Then enthusiastically redirect your child to the next activity like washing hands before dinner.

12548.text: You can also spend One-on-One Time with all of your children at once!

12738.text: Start in a circle and pass one snap around the circle (or clap if you cannot snap)

12755.text: You snap once to throw the snap and once to catch it. Look at the person you are throwing to.

12777.text: The direction (up, down, straight, curved, rolling the ground) and force (hard, soft, medium) that you throw the snap should affect how the person catches it.

12805.text: You can bounce the snap, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it.

12826.text: When everyone gets good at this, you can start moving around the room, still passing the snap.

12845.text: Can you throw under the leg?  Behind the back?  Through your head?  Intercept a pass? Have fun with the snap!

14327.text: Hello! How are you feeling? If you are feeling overwhelmed or stress, here's a fun activity that can also release some stress.

14349.text: Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the Sunshine of Positive Attention shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.

14386.text: Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction

14415.text: Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!

14437.text: Let your hand hang by your side. Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you relax your body.

14471.text: Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out. Repeat 4 times.

14500.text: Relax your arms and let them swing to the front and back. Take 4 deep breaths while you do this. This is good for your lower back.

14527.text: Relax your arms and let your arms to swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.

14556.text: Take a moment to reflect on your experience. Remember that you can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.

14589.text: Hello! Did you know that 3 is a magical number? Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?

14625.text: What are your three favourite foods? Can you name three things you can see right now? Can you hear three sounds you can hear right now? What are three things you are grateful for right now?

14662.text: Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three? How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Three is a magical number!

14695.text: • Stop for a moment and close your eyes.

14705.text: • How many sounds can you hear? Listen to sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. (Pause for 10 seconds)

14729.text: • How many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?

14743.text: • Let’s try again. Can you hear any new sounds this time? Can you hear any sounds inside your own body? (Pause for 10 seconds)

14768.text: • Open your eyes. What new sounds did you hear?

14781.text: Baba da bi da ba da baaa! Pause Power!

14791.text: What’s Pause Power I hear you say? It’s the ability to transform from a grumpy, angry person into a calm, clear one.

14814.text: When I’m feeling frustrated I plant my feet firmly on the ground and I breathe in and out three times as slowly as I can. Sometimes I imagine I’m smelling a flower and blowing out a candle.

14852.text: Da ta! Pause Power! My transformation from grumpy to calm is complete!

And now think of one thing you did today that you don't feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow? And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.

15285.text: Here are 6 simple tips on how you can make household rules with your children and teens:

15303.text: 1. Involve your child in establishing household rules.

15360.text: 6. Add only 1 household rule at a time.

15836.text: Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest

15872.text: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.

15890.text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Tooolbox! Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings

15938.text: Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).

15984.text: Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red apple and says “Tomato”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's an apple!”

16020.text: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.

16052.text: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.

16104.text: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.

16164.text: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!

16212.text: “Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”

16228.text: “The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”

16247.text: “That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”

16268.text: You can use books and stories to help talk with children about topics related to COVID-19 (such as getting sick, not going to school or work, staying indoors, feeling worried) and help them think about how this makes them feel.

16933.text: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.

16967.text: It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

17015.text: Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.

17060.text: Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing your baby close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and your baby will get through it together!

17107.text: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.

17142.text: Pay close attention to your baby in case they try something dangerous! Just because they are able to play on their own now, doesn’t mean you can look away for long. Redirect mischievous behaviours into practice waving, imitation games, singing and moving games and pretending to talk on the phone!

17192.text: Try to stay calm and support your toddler as they move through the tantrum. Your priority is to ensure that they don’t hurt themselves. Don’t add to your child’s anger by shouting and showing angry emotions. This won’t help.

17231.text: Babies are much more likely to want to do things if you make the activity fun and playful. Patience is also a must. Take a deep breath if you notice yourself getting frustrated by your baby.

18344.text: We are models of our children's behaviour. If we practice keeping safe distances, handwashing and treat others with compassion, our children and teenagers will do the same.

18376.text: They like to be like me and you,

18384.text: What you do and what you say,

18391.text: Will help to shape them everyday!

18397.text: Routines will make your children feel safe and secure. Try to have regular mealtimes and bedtimes. Remember to schedule One-on-One time with your children, too!

18422.text: Did you know that teens actually like having responsibilities? It makes them feel more independent and grown up. Allow your teen to choose a special job that helps out.

18451.text: As your teen shows more responsibility, you can also give them extra privileges. Try to share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and girls/boys. Praise your teen whenever they do their job!

18481.text: When you teach your children about safe distancing, you keep your whole family safe. You keep others safe, too!

18500.text: You can even make safe distancing into a game where children earn points for keeping at least 1 metre away from others in public. The one with the most points can win a simple, free reward like extra One-on-One Time

19165.text: Look at your child and say their name when you give your child an instruction. Get down to their level.

19185.text: Step 2. Be Specific, Positive, and Realistic!

19192.text: Describe exactly what you want your child to do. Say, 'Please wash your hands for 20 seconds before coming to dinner, instead of 'Wash your hands.'

19218.text: Step 3. Give Instructions One at a Time

19226.text: Children are much more likely to do what you ask if you break things up into smaller steps.

19244.text: Use positive words when telling your child what to do. Say, ‘Please put your clothes away in the cupboard,’ instead of ‘Don’t make a mess’.

19269.text: Step 4. Praise Your Children When They Follow Instructions

19278.text: They will feel good about it and be more likely to follow instructions in the future!

20173.text: The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.

20380.text: Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!

20434.text: 2. Respond as soon as you can

20441.text: Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.

20477.text: 3.  Check to see why your baby is crying

20487.text: There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!

20539.text: Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!

20596.text: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.

20633.text: 6. Be gentle and patient with yourself

20640.text: We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all they can to calm them. You are doing your best!

20674.text: 7. If you think your baby is injured or sick, call or visit a clinic

20689.text: If your baby cries for a long time and does not stop, they might be injured or sick. You should seek medical help immediately.

20714.text: Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.

20748.text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Remember that there are no bad parents. We are all learning here!

20771.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about what to do when your baby is crying?

21442.text: Close your eyes and think about the day. Name 1 thing that you are grateful for. Name 1 thing that you did well. Name 1 think that you love. You earned a goodnight of sleep!

21477.text: Hi! How are you feeling right now? Are you feeling stressed and worried? Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful.

21507.text: Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready open your eyes again. Everything is okay.

21539.text: Feel ground beneath you. Feel your body. Bring your awareness to your breath.

21554.text: At the end of the day, take a minute to think about the day.

21570.text: Think about one positive or fun thing you did.

21579.text: Praise yourself for one thing you did well today.

21588.text: Think of one thing you can do differently tomorrow.

21598.text: Think of one thing that you are grateful for.

21612.text: Hi! Here is something fun to help you let go of stress:

21624.text: Choose a song that reflects what you need in this moment. Do you need a gentle song to soothe your tired soul or an upbeat song to help you shake some stress out?

21657.text: Make a space and move your body to the music. Remember to breathe while you move. Let your breath and the movement go together.

21681.text: Even a few minutes of movement can be enough to release stress and lift your mood!

21697.text: Hi! Do you sometimes feel like you are getting everything wrong?

21708.text: Take a moment to think over the day. Think of one thing you did today that you are proud of.

21728.text: Wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.

21739.text: Think of one thing you did today that you don’t feel proud of. What can you do differently tomorrow?

21758.text: And wrap your arms around your body and give yourself a hug.

21770.text: It’s ok. You are doing your best so be kind to yourself. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!

21789.text: Do your children ever make you feel like screaming? Give yourself a 10-second pause. Breath in and out slowly 5 times. Then try responding in a calmer way. Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.

21826.text: Hello! Do you sometimes feel your feelings are too much?

21840.text: Talk to someone you trust. Talk to a friend. Talk to family. Talk to a tree.

21856.text: Get your worries off your chest and then let them go. Even if it’s just for a moment.

21880.text: A joy shared is twice the joy. A problem shared is half the problem.

21896.text: Take a moment to stop what you are doing and connect with your breath.

21912.text: What is one thing you can be grateful for right now?

21923.text: What is one thing that brings you happiness?

21931.text: What is one thing that you love?

21938.text: They don't have to be big. Sometimes the small things in life count the most!

21955.text: Feeling down or desperate? Let’s use the magic power of three.

21967.text: Name three sounds you can hear right now.

21975.text: Name three smells you can smell right now.

21990.text: What are three things you can be grateful for right now?

22001.text: They don’t have to be big.

22007.text: At the end of a tough day, thinking of three things to be grateful for can help us find the courage to try again tomorrow.

22035.text: Hello! Do you feel alone or unsupported?

22043.text: Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.

22051.text: What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t?

22066.text: Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.

22076.text: Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground.

22094.text: Try this next time you feel alone or are doing a mundane activity like washing up. It can really help!

22114.text: Hi! Here is a short relaxation activity for you:

22123.text: Sit down and close your eyes

22129.text: How many sounds can you hear?

22136.text: Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers.

22150.text: After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?

22165.text: Try again for another ten seconds.

22172.text: Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body?

22192.text: Hi! How are you feeling? Do you feel angry or overwhelmed? Use the magic power of three.

22209.text: Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

22219.text: Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

22229.text: Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

22239.text: Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

22249.text: Breathe in to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

22259.text: Breath out to the count of three. 1, 2, 3.

22269.text: How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Deep breathing helps our whole body and mind to calm down.

22291.text: Hello! Are you feeling something so strongly that you want to run away from it?

22306.text: Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.

22320.text: It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.

22333.text: Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?

22354.text: Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself in this moment?

22377.text: If your mind starts to wander, it’s normal. Just bring it back to the feeling. Keep breathing and feeling.

22396.text: Reassure yourself. It’s ok to feel. Feeling is healing!

22405.text: Hello! How does your body feel right now? Here's an activity to relax your body:

22420.text: Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.

22429.text: Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head.

22443.text: Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful?

22463.text: Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain.

22490.text: Do this for a few breaths.

22497.text: Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?

22506.text: Try this next time you find yourself lying in bed unable to sleep!

22519.text: Thank you for making so much effort to be a better parent. You are loved and appreciated!

22536.text: There’s no such thing as a perfect parent or the perfect child. We are all just trying our best!

22555.text: Thank you for getting up every morning and trying again. Even when you are tired. That is real courage and dedication!

22577.text: Thank you for bringing the sunshine of positive attention into your family. Keep shining!

22616.text: Has anyone told you how incredible you are for being there for your children during a global pandemic? There’s no guidebook for these challenging times but you’re doing it! That makes you amazing.

22820.text: Thank you for being an inspiration to other women. Keep shining that light of yours!

22836.text: Thank you for showing up for your family today and doing your best! You are appreciated!

22852.text: Well done for getting to the end of the day! Sometimes that’s all we can do. Get some rest and try again tomorrow!

22875.text: Hooray! Trust that your hard work is bearing sweet fruits, even if you can’t taste them yet!

22892.text: Sometimes it’s easy, sometimes it’s not. Let go of the mistakes and celebrate the wins, however small!

22909.text: Every time you take a pause is an act of kindness. Thank you for being kind to yourself and your family today!

22931.text: It’s the end of the day! You did it! Now it’s time for you. You deserve

22948.text: Congratulations! You are doing amazing! Remember it’s the small things that make the big difference.

22963.text: Whatever you feel you did ‘wrong’ today, let it go and try again tomorrow. It’s ok!

22980.text: You made a difference today by showing up. Your down time starts now!

22993.text: Well done for trying to figure everything out. Nobody has all the answers but you really do your best!

23012.text: Taking care of yourself is taking care of your kids! Well done for taking a pause today. Keep it up!

23033.text: Ten points for you today! Together we can overcome any challenge.

23044.text: Well done for spending One-on-One time with your family! Time is the most valuable gift you can give them.

23064.text: Thank you for your kindness and patience today! Even when it’s tough, your words of praise, your smile and your attention are like sunshine for your children.

23091.text: Your curiosity and creativity are paying off! Give yourself a hug!

23102.text: Top marks for effort! It’s not easy but you tried your best. That’s all you can ever do!

23120.text: Happy, sad, angry, excited, worried? Well done for recognizing how you and others felt today! And remember, tomorrow is a brand new day.

25766.text: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.

25782.text: Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities:

25798.text: 1. Keep your child safe and well

25805.text: 2. Try to understand what they are feeling

25822.text: 5. Make things that you do the same every day to help them feel secure

25837.text: 6. Ask for help if you can

25876.text: Step 1. Keep your child safe and well

25885.text: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and also help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home

25912.text: • Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see

25921.text: Step 2. Try to understand how they are feeling

25930.text: • Your child may be feeling a lot of stress, anxiety, and frustration.

25943.text: • Tell them that you love them

25949.text: • Praise them for being good and for trying to be good!

25961.text: Step 3. Talking and communicating with your child

25969.text: • Get down to your child’s level when you speak.

25986.text: • Give them time to tell you or show you what they think

25999.text: • Tell your child that you understand

26006.text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about how to support children living with disabilities.

26027.text: Here is a link to disability services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

26051.text: • Praise them for behaving well, and for trying.

26061.text: • Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.

26072.text: • Only help children when they need it. It is also good to build independence!

26087.text: Step 5. Make daily plans to help them feel secure

26097.text: • Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.

26112.text: • Make a daily plan that includes some things they like to do.

26125.text: • Help your child connect to friends and family members through phone, writing cards, or drawing pictures.

26142.text: Step 6. Ask for help if you can

26150.text: • Share the load with other adult family members.

26159.text: •  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.

26173.text: • Share your challenges AND your successes.

26180.text: • It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.

26193.text: • Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!

26206.text: • Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.

26221.text: • Use simple language and clear instructions. If words aren't good for them, try gestures and pictures.

26239.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about how to support children living with disabilities?

26397.text: All children develop at different rates. But there are some things that we expect children to be able to do at an age. These are called ‘development’ milestones.

26425.text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to learn more about child development.

26442.text: Many things affect our children's development. For example, development is helped by eating healthy food, having immunisations, and parents or caregivers who talk to them a lot.

26470.text: If you are concerned that your child might be delayed in their development, here is a link to services in your area that may also be helpful: [INSERT LOCAL LINK]

26562.text: • Us to provide food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety.

26572.text: • A strong bond with parent/ caregiver.

26579.text: • Lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!

26604.text: • Become a curious little explorer - watch out for climbing!

26616.text: • Learn through play and trying things out

26624.text: • Want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions.

26641.text: • Want your praise and your approval

26652.text: • More interested in learning in school.

26659.text: • Start to want independence and trust.

26666.text: • Want to spend time with other children and young teenagers.

26677.text: • May be interested in religion or spirituality

26687.text: • 0–6 months: Smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.

26705.text: • 6–11 months: Cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened.

26718.text: • 12–23 months: Start to walk, talk and explore things around them!

26733.text: • Start speaking in sentences and  learning new words.

26743.text: • Does not like to lose or take turns, but sharing can be taught.

26757.text: • May express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!). Can start to learn how to manage their feelings.

26782.text: • May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.

26793.text: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive

26800.text: • Can learn to better manage anger and tolerate frustration.

26826.text: • Feelings get hurt easily and have mood swings

26835.text: • Try to be the boss and are unhappy if they lose.

26869.text: • Find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. Still express feelings in dramatic ways!

26888.text: • Their friends are important and affect their choices

26897.text: • Need some freedom but also reliable rules that don't change

26908.text: • Need affection, reassurance, self-esteem, encouragement to believe in their abilities

26923.text: • May talk a lot; ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more

26952.text: • Does not like to lose, share or take turns, but losing and taking turns can be taught.

26974.text: • The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!

26987.text: • Your child is almost an adult, they are able to communicate with you about

27004.text: • They can think about new ideas, develop their own ideals and set their

27036.text: • Starts to want independence and trust.

27043.text: • Wants to spend time with other children.

27055.text: • They are forming their own identity and have a growing sense of their

27070.text: • They may prefer being with peers more than with you

27081.text: • They may show risk-taking behaviours, frequent mood swings, and rebellious

27092.text: attitudes. They can also have exciting new ideas!

27104.text: • May start to ask questions about religion

27112.text: • May answer back to adults to show that they “know”.

27123.text: • Can be very self-conscious and sensitive. May be very active. By now they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.

27146.text: The most important things that you can do for your teen in this stage are:

27161.text: • Continue providing love, support and guidance and build a strong

27174.text: • Monitor who their friends are, have clear rules to keep them safe

27191.text: • Be patient and accepting of the person they are becoming - even if it is not what you had imagined

27212.text: • Encourage them to begin to take responsibility for the future

27223.text: • Keep supporting them and loving them so that they feel comfortable, secure, and safe

27238.text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Knowing about child development can help you feel less frustrated by them.

29862.text: Hello! We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving, money, and COVID-19 can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.

29890.text: Stop the river at the source. The same things usually make us get stressed and angry every time. What makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?

29921.text: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.

29955.text: Here are some things that can help make it less likely that bad things happen when you are angry:

31122.text: Here are 6 tips that can help you keep your children safe online:

31135.text: 1. Learn about the risks and dangers

31146.text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits

31153.text: 4. Spend time with your child online

31205.text: • Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.

31219.text: • Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography

31235.text: • Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.

31247.text: • Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.

31255.text: 2. Tech fixes to protect your children online:

31263.text: • Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.

31281.text: • Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.

31294.text: • Cover webcams when not in use.

31301.text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

31308.text: Involve your teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.

31320.text: Create device-free spaces and times in your house

31337.text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:

31380.text: Involve your child or teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.

31394.text: Create device-free spaces and times in your house

31415.text: This does not mean we should ban our children from spending time online. It just means that we need to learn how to protect them in a new world.

31444.text: Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!

31467.text: Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).

31480.text: Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.

31491.text: 4. Spend time with your child or teen online

31500.text: Get to know how your child experiences the digital world.

31510.text: Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.

31518.text: Talk to your teen on how to report things that aren't OK.

31530.text: Common Sense Media has great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.

31545.text: 5. Build open communication and trusting relationships

31552.text: Tell your children that if they experience something online (or anywhere) that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.

31590.text: INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals and the Child Helpline in your country to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

32249.text: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members

32285.text: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break

32321.text: Step 6. Do nice things together as a family

32330.text: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!

32354.text: Step 1. Be a model of behaviour for your kids

32364.text: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.

32395.text: Step 2. Use positive language. It works!

32402.text: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”

32434.text: Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”

32472.text: Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.

32495.text: You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.

32510.text: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference

32542.text: Bad communication between adults in the household can have a negative impact on our children. The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.

32755.text: Step 2. It is OK not to know the answers.

32765.text: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with your child. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn.

32815.text: Step 1. Be open, honest, and supportive

32822.text: Allow your child to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.

32841.text: Step 3. Be a hero not a bully

32849.text: Explain that COVID-19 has nothing to do with the way someone looks, where they are from, or what language they speak.

32871.text: Step 4. End on a good note

32878.text: Check to see if your child is okay. Remind them that you care and that they can talk to you anytime. Then do something fun together!

32904.text: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old your child is and how much they can understand.

32922.text: Your child may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.

32947.text: Tell your child that we can be compassionate to people who are sick and those who are caring for them.

33764.text: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night.

33798.text: It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

33831.text: Help your baby learn through play.  Put objects in your baby’s grasping hand, show them different materials, and answer when they ‘talk’ to you.

33857.text: Check to see why your baby is in a bad mood. Are they tired or hungry? Or maybe they are not feeling well? Or maybe they need some more loving attention. Be a reassuring presence for your baby when they are having a difficult day.

33902.text: Unfortunately, your baby will go through phases for the next 2 years of sleeping poorly. Try wearing your baby close to you, feeding them and carrying them in a sling. And hang in there, remember it’s a phase. You and your baby will get through it together!

33949.text: Your baby will cry as soon as a caregiver’s attention is diverted and are cranky as well as clingy. Prioritise being there for them and give them physical contact when needed.

34703.text: All children misbehave. It is normal when children are tired, hungry, afraid, or learning independence. One thing you can try is catching misbehavior early and distracting your kids’ attention to something positive. It actually works!

34739.text: It is completely normal to feel stressed, afraid, angry, and depressed during this time. You are not alone. These tips will help you take care of yourself so you can take care of your children.

34774.text: It is really hard to help our children continue learning when schools are closed or part-open. One thing that might be helpful is to try and set up a daily schedule that includes time for schoolwork and time for fun.

34814.text: It can be difficult to know how to talk your children about COVID-19, especially since we are learning about it too.

34836.text: The important thing is to be open and listen to your children. Be honest and supportive. Show them that you care.

34857.text: Parenting is really hard. But there are things we can do to make things easier. We are here to help!

34877.text: This is a stressful time for all of us. The more we listen to each other and show children how we keep ourselves healthy, the more they will feel secure and loved.

34909.text: Millions are stressed about money because of COVID-19. Children or teenagers asking for things can cause arguments.  It can help them a lot when we involve them with family budgeting.

34940.text: There are lots of risks to children online. But you can help protect your children by setting up easy tech fixes and creating health and safe online habits.

34968.text: Spending even just a few minutes a day focused on having fun with your children can help your relationship. If you are really busy it could be tidying or cleaning together - just make it fun!

35004.text: We spend a lot of time indoors with a young baby, and Covid-19 makes it much more intense.  It is completely normal to feel isolated, overwhelmed, anxious, and scared for you and your baby.

35599.text: • Cover your face with your hands.

35606.text: • Quickly show your face and say "Peek-a-Boo!" or "Hello!" Babies love it!

35620.text: Look at your baby in the eyes and make different funny faces.

35633.text: Make a big face. Make a small face. Make a happy face. Make a surprised face.

35650.text: Which ones make your baby smile or laugh? Do them again, even bigger this time!

35665.text: Play with different feelings and add sounds.

35673.text: Copy their facial expressions too. Exaggerate them to make them funny.

35684.text: Always end on a positive expression!

35692.text: • Get to your baby's level so they can see you and hear you.

35707.text: • Copy their facial expressions and sounds.

35715.text: • It is so simple while creating a strong bond between you and your baby!

35734.text: Lie your baby on their back after washing them or changing their diaper

35747.text: Tell them the sun is coming! Wiggle your fingers like sunrays above their head and make your face a big smiling sun.

35769.text: Tell them the wind is coming! Blow softly over their body.

35780.text: Tell them the rain is coming! Use your fingers to gently pat over their whole body like light raindrops.

35799.text: Tell them the clouds are coming! Wrap the towel or cloth around them like a blanket and cuddle them

35819.text: Play with different weathers. Which one does your baby like best?

35830.text: Add sound effects or make it into a little song. Use the tune of another song you know!

35850.text: Find an empty, clean plastic bottle or pot with a lid that closes tight.

35864.text: Fill it with sand, stones, uncooked rice, beans or any small objects that make an interesting sound.

35882.text: Move your body as you shake it in front of your baby

35894.text: If it is safe, give it to your baby to shake!

35905.text: Get creative! Can you find something colourful or try it with water?

35918.text: What sounds does your baby like?

35926.text: Put your baby on their back

35932.text: Wiggle their toe and say, “This little toe goes [funny sound]”

35943.text: Make a funny sound for each toe

35950.text: Play with different sounds. For example, animal sounds, popping sounds, squeaky sounds, fart sounds.

35965.text: Repeat this for all ten toes.

35972.text: Try to make the last toe the biggest and funniest sound!

35987.text: Sit on a chair and put your toddler on your lap facing you. Hold them firmly under the arms.

36006.text: Gently bounce your legs and say in a soft voice “Baby horse, baby horse, baby horse, baby horse”

36024.text: Bounce your legs a bit more and say a bit louder “Little horse, little horse, little horse, little horse”

36043.text: Bounce your legs more and say louder “Big horse, big horse, big horse, big horse”

36058.text: When you call out “Down in a ditch!” open your knees and let your child drop down between them. Make sure you hold them so they don’t fall far!

36090.text: Put on your favourite music or sing your favourite song and dance around the room with your toddler. If you have a baby hold them while you dance.

36119.text: Dance in different ways or with different parts of your body

36130.text: For example, “Dance like a monkey”, “Dance like a chicken” or “Let’s dance with our knees and hips”

36148.text: Think up different instructions. Be seriously playful!

36156.text: When the music stops, everyone does a funny freeze

36165.text: Notice what rhythms or movement they like!

36173.text: When your baby or toddler cries, sing a soft song to calm you both down

36188.text: Sing a soothing song you know or make up your own with a simple melody and some soothing words

36207.text: Repeat it over and over in a rhythmical way. For example, “My little one, oh little one”

36224.text: Sing the same song regularly so your child gets used to it!

36240.text: Look around you and name something that you can see. For example, a tree or a cup

36257.text: Say to your child “I see a tree, let’s be it”

36268.text: Countdown from 5 and make the shape of a tree with your bodies. Be as big and silly as possible.

36288.text: Now let your child have a turn. What can they see?

36299.text: If you can, go outside and be in nature. If you can’t, play it inside.

36315.text: When you’ve done it a few times, add moves and sounds!

36328.text: Children love to do what you do!

36335.text: Let your baby play with pots and spoons while you are making dinner

36348.text: At the End of the Day

36354.text: At the end of each day, take a minute to think about the day.

36370.text: Talk your child about one positive or fun thing they did.

36381.text: Praise yourself for one thing you did well today.

36390.text: Think of one thing that you are grateful for.

36409.text: Call out, “There’s rain on the mountain”

36416.text: Everyone else replies “Run, run, run” while running around the space.

36428.text: Call out different instructions. For example, touch something red or hop like a frog

36442.text: Keep playing and change the instructions each time.

36451.text: You can use this as a fun way to learn colours or even tidy up!

36469.text: Play or sing your favourite music and dance around the room

36480.text: Dance in different ways or with different parts of your body

36491.text: For example, “Dance like a monkey”, “Dance like a chicken” or “Dance with just our knees and hips”

36509.text: Think up different instructions. Be seriously playful!

36517.text: When the music stops, everyone does a funny freeze.

36527.text: Give your child a chance to be the one to stop the music!

36544.text: Sit down and close your eyes

36550.text: How many sounds can you hear? Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers

36570.text: After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear?

36585.text: Try again for another ten seconds.

36592.text: Can you hear any new sounds? Can you hear any sounds inside your own body?

36607.text: Notice how you feel and ask your child how they are feeling.

36688.text: You told us that you are a parent/caregiver of a young child (2 to 9 years) and teenager (10 to 17 years).

36710.text: You told us that you are a parent/caregiver of baby (0 to 23 months old) and young child (2 to 9 years).

36732.text: You told us that you are a parent/caregiver of a baby (0 to 23 months old), young child (2 to 9 years) and teenager (10 to 17 years).
